questions.question: Do any two categorical mushroom attributes appear to be related, or are they independent? Return as JSON with keys: column1, column2, chi_squared, p_value, degrees_of_freedom, expected_min, independent.
questions.hint: Pick two categorical columns with a modest number of levels, create a contingency table, and apply a chi‑squared test of independence.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 7 keys: "column1" (first categorical column), "column2" (second categorical column), "chi_squared" (test statistic rounded to 4 decimals), "p_value" (rounded to 6 decimals), "degrees_of_freedom" (integer), "expected_min" (minimum expected frequency rounded to 2 decimals), and "independent" (boolean, true if p >= 0.05). Example: {"column1": "gender", "column2": "product", "chi_squared": 15.2345, "p_value": 0.004321, "degrees_of_freedom": 4, "expected_min": 5.23, "independent": false}

questions.question: Which attributes in the dataset have more than 5% missing values? Return as JSON with keys: count, columns.
questions.hint: Compute missing percentages for each column and list those above the 5% threshold.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 2 keys: "count" (integer) and "columns" (list of column names, alphabetically sorted). Example: {"count": 3, "columns": ["col_a", "col_b", "col_c"]}

questions.question: Are there any features in this mushroom dataset that have a high proportion of missing values? Return as JSON with keys: count, columns.
questions.hint: Compute the missing percentage for each column and list those above a 10% threshold.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 2 keys: "count" (integer) and "columns" (list of column names, alphabetically sorted). Example: {"count": 3, "columns": ["col_a", "col_b", "col_c"]}
